awd_titl_txt: RAPID: STEM faculty support to address impacts from COVID-19 on Tribal Colleges and Universities Program institutions
awd_abstract_narration:
A goal of the Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP) is to increase the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) instructional and research capacities of specific institutions of higher education that serve the Nation's indigenous students. Expanding the STEM curricular offerings at these institutions expands the opportunities of their students to pursue challenging, rewarding careers in STEM fields, provides for research studies in areas that may be culturally significant, and encourages a community and generational appreciation for science and mathematics education, and sustainability of capacity gains is significantly enhanced by retaining the talent of credentialed STEM faculty. This project aligns directly with that goal.

The coronavirus pandemic of 2020-2021 caused major disruptions to institutions of higher education. However, for tribal colleges and universities, whose core operating funds are directly aligned with student enrollment, drops in enrollment equate to loss of funding. To mitigate against detrimental effects on STEM instructional capacity, this award will support the position of one full-time STEM faculty member, as well as other resources to maintain Red Lake Nation College’s STEM program as it recovers from the impact of the pandemic.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this project is to reduce COVID-19 pandemic-related negative impacts on Red Lake Nation College (RLNC) STEM instructional and programming capacity by supporting the salary and professional development of one full-time STEM faculty member teaching science and environmental studies. Specifically, the objectives included supporting the salary of one biology faculty, providing professional development opportunities for that biology faculty, and acquiring supplemental lab equipment to support online and in person biology classes.

Funding supported one year of salary and benefits for Red Lake Nation College Biology Instructor Tami Nendick, providing helpful support for maintaining STEM faculty during the COVID-19 pandemic. Ms. Nendick was able to attend the National Science Teachers Conference in Houston March 31 to April 3, 2022. She was also able to take two graduate biology courses at Bemidji State University, BIOL 5930: Medical Imaging and BIOL 5470: Introduction to Vaccinology. This provided Ms. Nendick and the RLNC STEM department with additional credentials.

In addition, two microscopes and a subscription to Labster, science teaching lab software assisted with online and in person biology lab courses.

This funding greatly assisted in supporting Red Lake Nation College STEM faculty and biology course offerings during the financial challenges of the COVID-19 pandemic.

 


Last Modified: 09/24/2024
Modified by: Lane Azure
